1.text:
>>>>The expansion of the Roman Republic in
the 2nd century BC brought in its train enormous

7.text:
social transformations that would have unintended
political consequences. We've seen how the

13.text:
Bacchanalian conspiracy, the anxiety about
this kind of religious movement, underground

18.text:
religious movement, is part of this gradual
change in Roman society. The consuls, in a

24.text:
sense fear what they can't control in this
urban environment, where there are nighttime

29.text:
religious festivals that have allegedly foreign
influences come from Greece. That's part of

35.text:
the social changes--religion is one dimension.
We want to consider the economic dimensions

41.text:
of the transformations in 2nd century Rome,
and the consequences of economic change for

46.text:
the political crisis of the Republic. And
we'll do so through the eyes of one of the

50.text:
great figures of late republican politics,
Tiberius Gracchus. The career of Tiberius

57.text:
would represent the beginning of a new, acute
phase of crisis within the republican system,

63.text:
and it's precisely because of his political
ideas and his ideas for a land reform that

69.text:
the Republic will enter a period of outright
political violence that would ultimately lead

75.text:
to the end of the Republic itself. Tiberius
was born into the wealthiest strands of the

81.text:
Roman aristocracy, from the elite of the elite.
The Roman aristocracy of this period is a

86.text:
military aristocracy. They're a wealthy, traditional
set of families, all of which compete with

92.text:
each other for military commands. And so the
sons of the aristocracy in this world serve

98.text:
as military officers. And Tiberius was serving
as a military officer and returning from a

104.text:
campaign in Spain when he traveled down the
coast of what's now Tuscany, then Etruria,

110.text:
a most important region to the north of Rome.
And as he traveled along the coast road, looking

115.text:
inland at the land that he saw, and he could
visualize almost in a flash in the image that

120.text:
he could see there off the coast, the problems
that faced Roman society. For he witnessed

126.text:
not a landscape carved up into small farms,
but a landscape dominated by enormous, slave-staffed

134.text:
villas. Tiberius could see these large villas
owned by the aristocracy of Rome that controlled

141.text:
huge amounts of land, that were stocked with
slaves who performed the agricultural labor

146.text:
to produce commodities, above all wine, that
then could be sold in foreign markets, bringing

151.text:
enormous wealth to the Roman elite. And in
that image of this landscape carved up into

157.text:
enormous slave plantations that didn't allow
the small farmer who was the traditional backbone

163.text:
of the Roman Republic to flourish, Tiberius
sensed the fundamental problems that would

170.text:
face the Roman Republic for the rest of its
history. And these problems that Tiberius

175.text:
sensed were at the heart of all of the changes
of the 2nd century: the urbanization of Rome,

182.text:
the growth of slavery, the expansion of markets,
the opportunities to make enormous wealth

187.text:
off of commerce, and that it changes within
the military, all of which would contribute

192.text:
to the demise of the small farmer. Tiberius
wasn't content simply to watch this transformation

199.text:
undermine his Republic, and he conceived a
brilliant political reform that would try

205.text:
to turn back some of these changes and would
restore the small farmer--the backbone of

210.text:
the Republic. Tiberius ran for office and
became a tribune in the Roman Republican system.

218.text:
Now the tribune was a very particular office
within the Roman system of magistrates. By

223.text:
this time, there were ten tribunes elected
annually. And the tribune had a very specific

228.text:
function in the Roman Republican Constitution.
A tribune was a defender of the common person.

234.text:
The tribune's role in the Republican Constitution
was to protect the ordinary man, and the tribune

241.text:
had exceptional powers that allowed him to
do so. The tribunes were sacrosanct.

247.text:
They were absolutely protected in their person,
in their safety, because they had to be willing

254.text:
to stand up for ordinary people, sometimes
against powerful interests. The tribune's

259.text:
powers included above all the veto--the ability
to say, "I prohibit this legislation from

267.text:
being enacted." So the tribune had the fundamental
power to say no, to stand in the way of changes

273.text:
that would harm the ordinary Roman citizen.
And the tribune would use these powers to

278.text:
protect the interests of the common man. And
so Tiberius, although from one of the bluest

282.text:
blood families in all of Roman society, became
an officer whose role was to protect ordinary

289.text:
Romans -- and he did so on a very particular
platform. He ran on an idea of land reform,

296.text:
what we can call the Tiberian land reforms.
Tiberius proposed to rehabilitate an ancient

303.text:
law, the Licinian law that was passed in 367
BC, so we're talking about a law that's 200

310.text:
years old. This law said that no individual
then can own over a certain amount--500 jugera

316.text:
is about 40 family farms, it's a very significant
amount of land--of ager publicus, of public

323.text:
land: A particular kind of land that was classified
within the Roman legal system, land that had

328.text:
been conquered by the Roman armies. Tiberius
says, in effect, I am going to enforce this

334.text:
obsolete, ancient law that's more than 200
years old that limits the upper size of properties,

340.text:
landed properties, on a certain classification
of land. There were certainly many estates

346.text:
owned by the Roman aristocracy that far exceeded
this scale of landholding. It would be like

352.text:
if we found a law that was 200 years old,
so imagine a law that was passed in the presidency

357.text:
of George Washington, that had fallen into
desuetude that said something like, "No individual

363.text:
can own more than 100 acres" or "No individual
can own more than say $500,000," maybe that's

369.text:
a better a way of estimating it. But today
that would seem very small, and that must

373.text:
of been something that like the way the Roman
aristocracy reacted to the reforms of Tiberius.

379.text:
That he had found this ancient law that was
technically on the books but was largely obsolete,

384.text:
and intended to enforce it so he would set
upper limits to the size of their properties.

390.text:
Well, what this amounted to was a seizure
of properties, and we have remnants of the

394.text:
kinds of debates that happened in the context
of his proposals. The aristocrats said, "We've

400.text:
owned this property. We've occupied this property.
We've improved this property. We've invested

405.text:
capital to improve this land. This has been
our home. Our ancestors' tombs are on this

411.text:
land, and you're simply going to seize it
by enforcing some obsolete law?" But the small

417.text:
farmer had a different kind of case. Imagine
the veteran saying, "This is public land,

423.text:
this is land that was conquered by the Roman
armies, the armies that ordinary citizens

427.text:
and soldiers, such as myself, had served in."
Tiberius proposed to take the land that he

433.text:
was going to redistribute and give it to small
farmers, especially veterans--men who had

439.text:
served their republic in the army, to give
it to poor people, to ordinary people. And

444.text:
so the land reform that he proposes has a
very profound class-based impact. The wealthy,

452.text:
the aristocrats who own large tracts of land,
oppose this kind of reform and see it as an

458.text:
egregious act of theft, of the state stealing
their land and redistributing it. The small

464.text:
farmer sees it as a wise, republican reform,
sees it as a way for the Republic to revitalize

472.text:
itself, to give what is due to those who have
served in the Roman army. Tiberius is brought

479.text:
into office on this platform, but he faces
immediate opposition, in fact, opposition

485.text:
from one of his colleagues, one of the other
tribunes, who also has the veto power and

490.text:
who represents the interests not of the common
man, but of the wealthy, senatorial aristocracy,

496.text:
and who begins to use his veto power to block
Tiberius's efforts to redistribute land. There's

503.text:
a certain irony in this that another tribune,
who should be acting in the interests of the

507.text:
common Roman, uses his powers to block the
land reforms of Tiberius. Tiberius is furious

515.text:
and he makes every maneuver he can to try
and overcome his opponent, to try and dissuade

520.text:
him. He, in fact, takes extreme measures.
He practices what we would consider a government

526.text:
shutdown. He begins vetoing every single act
of every single magistrate in the Roman Republic,

532.text:
shutting down the entire system of government.
And when his colleague still refuses to budge,

537.text:
Tiberius proposes an unprecedented action.
He proposes that his colleague, his fellow

543.text:
tribune, be impeached, be turned out of office
because he's failing to protect the interest

548.text:
of the common man. This is a radical and unprecedented
act, and it scared even Tiberius's own supporters,

555.text:
who realize that if the tribune could be thrown
out of office that it would set, in fact,

561.text:
a dangerous precedent that would undermine
the office of the tribune in the long run.

566.text:
Because then it meant that a tribune taking
unpopular action could simply be turned out

570.text:
of office. Nevertheless, Tiberius was intent,
and he had his colleague thrown out of office.

575.text:
And he then stood unimpeded, and was able
to begin enforcing his land reforms. Tiberius

583.text:
and his brother and another ally begin to
carry out their land reforms. And we know

590.text:
that already in this year, 133 BC, that his
land commission is taking action to redistribute

596.text:
land. But as the year progressed his progress
was continually impeded by the Senate, who

603.text:
didn't wish to see his land reforms carried
through. And as the year reached its end,

609.text:
so would Tiberius's tenure as tribune, and
Tiberius knew that if he was no longer tribune

615.text:
that first his land reforms would be undermined,
and that secondly, he himself would be in

621.text:
grave danger. No longer protected by the office
itself, he would probably be a likely target

626.text:
of political violence. And so Tiberius took
another extraordinary act. He ran for reelection

634.text:
as tribune, again violating tradition within
the Roman Republican Constitution. And as

641.text:
Tiberius campaigned for reelection this time,
the campaign itself became clouded by an atmosphere

647.text:
of violence. His opponents, especially the
wealthy senatorial aristocracy, accused him

653.text:
of aiming at tyranny. They accused him of
taking unprecedented actions, having his colleagues

659.text:
thrown out of office, having himself reelected
beyond his term, so that he could redistribute

665.text:
land. In the eyes of the aristocrats, he was
a dangerous demagogue. But to his own constituency,

673.text:
the common people of Rome, he was a hero.
His reelection campaign was marked by an air

679.text:
of increasing violence, and on the day of
the election itself, Tiberius went into the

685.text:
heart of Rome and where he was surrounded
by a mob of people. Another group of senators

692.text:
meeting on the other side of Rome set out
across the city and came to Tiberius and slew

698.text:
him, killing him, spilling blood in the streets
of Rome. Tiberius was assassinated by a band

705.text:
of senators who claimed to be acting in the
name of republican liberty, in the name of

710.text:
the constitution. Who claimed the be acting
against a dangerous demagogue, who had broken

715.text:
precedent time and again to carry out his
reforms. Tiberius claimed to be acting in

722.text:
the interest of the common man, to be upholding
the values of the Republic against the wealthy

729.text:
interests that were undermining it. The career
of Tiberius Gracchus above all proves how

735.text:
fundamentally important it is within a republic,
a res publica, to maintain a community of

741.text:
interest. The career of Tiberius Gracchus
teaches this lesson: That when the interests

746.text:
of different elements of society are so divergent
that they lack the ability to form a consensus,

753.text:
that violence becomes possible. And the assassination
of Tiberius Gracchus was the beginning of

759.text: a new and more violent period of Roman politics.
